awd_titl_txt: Enhancing research capacity on Cape Cod for studies of coastal ecosystems that are at risk from climate change and other human impacts
awd_abstract_narration:
The effects of climate change and other human impacts can be challenging to assess, especially for long‐lived, cryptic species. The Center for Coastal Studies (CCS, www.coastalstudies.org) has studied threatened and endangered species and vulnerable coastal ecosystems for more than four decades. This project establishes a molecular genetic/omics laboratory to enhance multidecadal, inter‐disciplinary and collaborative biological research. A dedicated lab on Cape Cod will facilitate the study of coastal and marine species, with particular support for long‐term cetacean research, including studies of human impacts by providing forensic data, insights into genetic diversity and fitness, and the evolutionary context for modern population responses.  The lab will serve the extensive regional scientific community, provide hands‐on opportunities for students and support the needs of management agencies. Public outreach has the potential to reach 20,000 adults and children each year through CCS outreach and education programs.

The molecular genetics lab is an expansion of the CCS Integrated Analytical Laboratory in Provincetown, Massachusetts, and would be equipped for genetic and genomic assays, such as “genotype‐by‐sequencing” and whole genome sequencing, as well as in‐house bioinformatics and data analysis. The lab further benefits from a partnership with the Marine Evolution and Conservation Lab at the University of Groningen, a well‐established laboratory and the primary repository for genetic samples of North Atlantic whale species.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this infrastructure grant was to obtain major instrumentation for a new genetic/omics lab at the Center for Coastal Studies (Provincetown, MA).  This lab is an extension of the NSF-funded Integrated Analytical Laboratory as well as a collaboration with a well-established genetics laboratory at the University of Groningen in the Netherlands.  The new facilities have enhanced the Center’s long-term involvement in genetic research, and provided services and opportunities for researchers, resource managers and students on Cape Cod and beyond.  The lab is equipped for genotyping, whole genome sequencing and gene expression analysis in addition to in-house bioinformatics and data analysis.  It includes a state-of-the-art pipetting robot to ensure bench work efficiency and consistency, as well as hands-on learning opportunities for new users, students and interns without a trade-off in research quality.  A Quantstudio Absolute digital PCR provides in-house options for epigenetics, wildlife disease monitoring and other research.  The grant has also expanded the Center’s cryogenic storage capacity and provided options for temporary and long-term storage assistance for regional collaborators.  The initial priority of the lab is to continue and enhance mammal research, including the effects of climate change and other human impacts on populations, but planning is underway to expand to other local species.  This new facility will prioritize the participation of under-represented groups and provide public outreach on the importance of genetic/omics for understanding coastal and marine life.  


Last Modified: 03/31/2024
Modified by: Jooke Robbins
por.por_txt_cntn:
The purpose of this infrastructure grant was to obtain major instrumentation for a new genetic/omics lab at the Center for Coastal Studies (Provincetown, MA). This lab is an extension of the NSF-funded Integrated Analytical Laboratory as well as a collaboration with a well-established genetics laboratory at the University of Groningen in the Netherlands. The new facilities have enhanced the Centers long-term involvement in genetic research, and provided services and opportunities for researchers, resource managers and students on Cape Cod and beyond. The lab is equipped for genotyping, whole genome sequencing and gene expression analysis in addition to in-house bioinformatics and data analysis. It includes a state-of-the-art pipetting robot to ensure bench work efficiency and consistency, as well as hands-on learning opportunities for new users, students and interns without a trade-off in research quality. A Quantstudio Absolute digital PCR provides in-house options for epigenetics, wildlife disease monitoring and other research. The grant has also expanded the Centers cryogenic storage capacity and provided options for temporary and long-term storage assistance for regional collaborators. The initial priority of the lab is to continue and enhance mammal research, including the effects of climate change and other human impacts on populations, but planning is underway to expand to other local species. This new facility will prioritize the participation of under-represented groups and provide public outreach on the importance of genetic/omics for understanding coastal and marine life.
